comments.content: its typical IT language to refer to it as ECC RAM tho..
loool that's funny don't come back with a tire or engine lol
I think the question is trying to fool you. While ECC RAM is a real thing and mostly like the right answer if it was there, it only says "ECC", the feature, not "ECC RAM".
The question clearly mentions 'which RAM type' - therefore all answers are assumed to be RAM types and not the feature

Are you seriously kidding me rn!!!

It is asking RAM type though, ECC is also a ram type isn't it?

discussion.content: when someone ask you to bring them a CAR , you don't come back with a tire or an engine, ECC is a feature on a ram but is not a ram.
Why? I think it should be D, since servers use ECC memory to prevent data loss.

comments.content: ECC itself is not a ram type, apparently....

Selected Answer: D
its D. ECC 
the others are used for Laptops and not servers

Selected Answer: D

im gonna go with ECC. Its asking type..
"BEST RAM type" - the keyword in the question is 'type', not RAM module. ECC is a RAM 'type' designated for server use.

Selected Answer: D
I think its D again I know DDR4 makes more sense but this is COMPTIA. They don't ask you straight up questions they ask you what answers they want.

Selected Answer: D
Yes, I think D, ECC is the intended answer here. Might not be totally right, but I'm here to pass the test
D. ECC is the answer, folks

I am sad to see DDR4 as answer coz I thought ECC was used in servers. However, the total misleading question was what the technician should retrieve not add. So, in order to update the memory, it must have been a lower one,that is DDR4 and afterwards he can update it to ECC. That might be a reason for the answer

comments.content: I have also applied the same logic, he will perform an update for improvement, then he will remove the DDR4.

discussion.content: DDR4 ECC
What???? it should be DRR4 ECC
The answer should be D ECC
this is a poorly written question, however through process of elimination b. is a type of memory a. is a form factor c. is a feature d. is a feature

This would have to be DDR4. The technician would already know to choose DDR4 ECC. Just saying ECC wouldn't guarantee that the technician chose memory that would upgrade the system. If the system currently has DDR2 installed, DDR1 ECC memory would represent a downgrade.

I believe the answer is D. domino500 definitely makes a good point that ECC is a feature but the question is asking to "upgrade" their ram. ECC ram is very common in a server because it provides data protection, and can detect and correct memory errors.

I think D is the correct answer, as per Dion - OBJ-3.3: Error-correcting code memory (ECC memory) is a type of computer data storage that can detect and correct the most common kinds of internal data corruption. ECC memory is used in most computers where data corruption cannot be tolerated under any circumstances, such as scientific or financial computing and mission-critical servers.
I think the hint here is "Server". Desktops typically do not use ECC. Only servers. They might want you to be aware of it.
Believe or not but correct answer is ECC
ECC is not a RAM type; just an integration to correct errors of SDRAM or DDR RAM types. Hence, DDR4 would be suitable for upgrade as it offers higher data transfer rates than DDR3.
I assume ECC is not a ram type, but the ability of ram. For example there is DDR4 Ram as ECC and non ECC, just as there is SO Dimm as ECC and non ECC. What do you think is that possible?

Error correction code (ECC) memory is a type of RAM memory found in workstations and servers. It's valued by professionals and businesses with critical data for its ability to automatically detect and correct memory errors, thus fighting data corruption. ECC is the answer.
"technician has been tasked with retrieving the RAM from storage and then installing it.". You can install DDR4 and not ECC.
The correct answer is ECC. DDR4 is not compatible with any earlier type of RAM, hence the technician can't just upgrade the server with a DDR4 unless he knows the RAM prior.

What is the "BEST" Ram...
Although some servers are best served with ECC, ECC itself it is not a RAM type I guess.

Correct answer should be D

This is a RAM UPGRADE. key word "upgrade". We are not replacing the motherboard and you can't freely choose the RAM that goes into a motherboard because of physical design incompatibility (look up "notches" on DD2vsDD3vsDDR4).
The best answer would be is DDR4 ecc-Ram type, because the question asked about the upgrade option for the Ram..

I strongly believe the answer DDR4 is wrong. I went with it and failed that 3.3 objective. The question needs to be update and simplified so its not ambiguous. Something like, What RAM would you expect to use in a modern server? Or, what RAM would you expect to use in a modern PC being used as a server?

Hi there,

I had exactly this question in my exam.

Any other thoughts about domain selection?

I received a question about a server grade laptop that was worded in a slightly similar way. One would assume SODIMM would've been the correct answer, but it wasn't even listed. I had to choose between DDR4 and LRDIMM.

discussion.content: I too believe it should be ECC. Now if the question stated what type of RAM was in the server already, DDR3 or DDR4, then DDR4 makes sense.
Unless you upgrade the MOBO for ECC, you can't use it. It's just an upgrade in RAM. Therefore, DDR4 is the way to go.
DDR4 is the best TYPE of RAM.

I agree the 'best choice' for servers is ECC RAM. The question does not state what type of RAM the server is compatible with, DDR4 / DDR3? But it is a server so we know that servers support ECC memory.
I think D is the better choice since server may use DDR3 on it system(Am I wrong?) and ECC is apply to all type of Memory

questions.question_text:
A server needs a RAM upgrade, and a technician has been tasked with retrieving the RAM from storage and then installing it.
Which of the following is the BEST RAM type for the technician to retrieve?

choices.C: Synchronize the device to a private cloud.
choices.A: Synchronize the device to a flash drive remotely.
choices.B: Synchronize data across the network to a shared public folder.
choices.D: Synchronize data to a virtual machine in the datacenter.

questions.question_text: A technology refresh will be performed on all mobile phones and PCs in a sales department. Joe, the sales manager, is concerned his personal data on his phone, such as contacts, pictures, and videos, will be replaced. Which of the following should be performed before the device is refreshed to save the data without compromising security?

discussion.content: how is it not A?

comments.content: You can't 'synchronise' to an SDD. You perform a 'backup' to the SSD locally, not 'remotely'.

questions.question_text: A technician is setting up a networked printer in a SOHO. Several users will frequently submit multipage reports, and the printer will use its own integrated print server for managing jobs. Which of the following should be configured to BEST keep the pages sorted?

discussion.content: Collate means if you are going to print a 4 page report 3 times it'll come out as 1/2/3/4 and then1/2/3/4 then 1/2/3/4, or else it'll normally print 1/1/1/2/2/2/3/3/3/4/4/4
Why it is a collate?

RAID 0 = very fast but no fault tolerance
RAID 1 = mirroring: so you need a even number of Disks
RAID 5 = fast and fault tolerance, you need 3 or more Disks
RAID 10 = very fast and fault tolerance, but you need 4 Disks or more, but a even number
You need 3 HDD drives to have RAID 5 (Stripping with Parity.) Meaning if one of your HDD drives fail you will still have fault tolerance and can save/restore data :).
Can someone please explain this?

questions.question_text: A technician is setting up the storage on a server and uses three SCSI hot-swappable hard drives. The technician configures a RAID array that uses all three drives. Therefore, if one of the drives fails, it can be pulled and replaced with a new drive, and the array will rebuild itself. Which of the following RAID configurations is the technician setting up?

discussion.content:
a) - Hinges - can't be as it wasn't inferred to be physically damaged during the fall
b) Inverter - can't be as the fault isn't with the display 
c) - Antenna - can't be as the fault isn't with connectivity 
e) digitizer - can't be as it isn't a touch screen device 
-- bezel as that houses the mic and camera components.

questions.question_text: Joe, a user, dropped his laptop right before a company webinar. During the webinar, the other participants could hear but not see Joe. A technician ran system diagnostics and verified the camera was enabled. Replacing which of the following will MOST likely resolve the issue?
